clusters.title: 'Lived life to the fullest': Tributes to trio killed in light plane crash
clusters.neutral_headline: Tributes Paid After Light Plane Crash Kills Three
bullet_summary: Reported by 9News, ABC News Australia, Canberra Times

items.title: 'Lived life to the fullest': Tributes to trio killed in light plane crash
items.standfirst: Air crash investigators have spent the day south of Sydney, combing through the wreckage of a light plane crash which left three people dead.
items.content: Air crash investigators have spent the day combing through the wreckage of a light plane crash that left three people dead south of Sydney.The Albion Park community is mourning husband and wife Andrew and Julieanne Connors, and their family friend Colin McLaughlin.Investigators are meticulously documenting the spot where three lives were lost as locals pay their respects with flowers. READ MORE: Paedophile rock star Ian Watkins murdered in UK prison attack They trio were on board a light plane bound for Bathurst yesterday morning when it crashed at Shellharbour Airport in Albion Park.They're being remembered as pillars of the community.Andrew's mates in the construction industry offered condolences to the Connors and McLaughlin families."You truly lived life to the fullest, and you've left a lasting impact on everyone lucky enough to have crossed paths with you," City Building Approvals wrote.Andrew and Julieanne ran Tumut Valley Holiday Park in the Snowy Mountains.Those who worked there with them called them "visionary leaders"."Their legacy will continue to inspire us as we carry forward the values they embodied," she said.With the site now carefully photographed, the plane is being taken away to be thoroughly examined, but it'll be months at least before investigators rule on the cause of the crash.READ MORE: Personal data of 5.7 million Qantas customers released onto dark web by hackers The Piper Cherokee Lance was built in 1975 and owned by the Connors family since 2013.Its maintenance records and flight history are now crucial evidence.

items.title: Friends pay tribute to 'fantastic people' killed in light plane crash
items.standfirst: Friends and neighbours of three people killed in a plane crash at Shellharbour Airport in New South Wales say their deaths are a "big loss to the community".
items.content: Friends and neighbours of three people killed in a plane crash at Shellharbour Airport in New South Wales say their deaths are a "big loss to the community".

items.title: 'Fun-loving' couple among three dead in light plane crash south of Sydney
items.standfirst: A married couple and their friend have been killed when their light plane crashed south of Sydney.
items.content: A married couple and their friend have been killed when their light plane crashed south of Sydney.Owner Andrew Connors, his wife Julieanne and family-friend Colin McLachlan were bound for Bathurst when the Piper Cherokee Lance aircraft they were travelling in crashed at Shellharbour Airport.The plane took off just before 10am and was in the air for a few seconds before the aircraft tilted onto one wing and crashed.READ MORE: Police investigating death of 63-year-old man at Melbourne train stationThe plane burst into flames on impact.NSW Fire and Rescue crews who were doing a training exercise nearby were suddenly faced with a real-life scenario."There was nothing anybody could have done for the occupants of the aeroplane," Andrew Barber said.READ MORE: Boy, 15, hit and killed by truck while walking to school in Victoria "It did disintegrate upon impact with the ground, one wing came off completely."Mr and Mrs Connors, who have been described by a friend as fun-loving, were on their way to race weekend with McLachlan.Mr Connors was known in the community for his company Connors Buildings. The Australian Transport and Safety Bureau is investigating the crash. NSW Police chief inspector Aaron Wunderlich said the crash happened in front of up to 15 witnesses, including fire crews and visitors at the nearby HARS Aviation Museum.Wunderlich thanked emergency services for their work at the scene of the tragic accident."They did a fantastic job of what was really a horrific scene," he said.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: 'A very tragic incident': Three people dead in fiery plane crash at Shellharbour airport
items.standfirst: "In all my time as a police officer I've never been to an aviation incident like this."
items.content: "In all my time as a police officer I've never been to an aviation incident like this."

ai_summary: A light plane crash near Sydney killed three people.
Air crash investigators examined the wreckage.
Friends described the victims as "fantastic people".
A married couple and their friend were among the deceased.
The crash occurred at Shellharbour Airport.

clusters.title: Personal data of 5.7 million Qantas customers released onto dark web by hackers
clusters.neutral_headline: Qantas Customer Data Released on Dark Web After Hack

items.title: Personal data of 5.7 million Qantas customers released onto dark web by hackers
items.standfirst: Qantas was one of 40 companies caught up in the hack, alongside the likes of Toyota, Disney and IKEA.
items.content: Millions of Australians are being warned to be alert for a rise in scam activity after the personal data of 5.7 million Qantas customers was released on the dark web by hackers.Qantas was one of 40 companies caught up in the hack, alongside the likes of Toyota, Disney and IKEA when the hacker group Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters stole almost 1 billion records of customer data from cloud technology company Salesforce in July.A threat to release the details had been made by the group earlier this weekREAD MORE: Delivery rider in hospital after his bike and fleeing Porsche crash"If Salesforce does not engage with us to resolve this, we will completely target each and every individual customers (sic) of theirs listed below, failure to comply will result in massive consequences," the statement from the hackers said.In response, Salesforce insisted it would not "engage, negotiate with, or pay any extortion demand".The hackers did not break into the Salesforce system, but instead called the IT desks of the 40 companies and posed as legitimate employees.In the case of Qantas, it is believed a call centre in the Philippines was targeted by the hackers.The information of Qantas passengers believed to have been released includes date of birth, emails and frequent flyer numbers.READ MORE: Teenage boy fighting for life after being bitten by sharkThis includes a string of politicians' home addresses and phone numbers, Cyber Security Coordinator Lieutenant General Michelle McGuinness confirmed in Senate estimates earlier this week."There has been a threat actor who has claimed to steal dataâ€¦ Qantas have notified all those who are impacted, and it may be that the threat actor has the data at this stage, the operational experts will, under normal circumstances, look to verify and that would be a question for our operational organisations," she said.It is not believed credit card details or passport numbers were compromised in the breach.Qantas has been contacted for comment.It previously told 9news.com.au: "Ensuring continued vigilance and providing ongoing support for our customers remain our top priorities following our cyber incident in early July."We continue to offer a 24/7 support line and specialist identity protection advice to affected customers and through the ongoing injunction we obtained through the NSW Supreme Court we have legal protections in place to prevent the stolen data being accessed or released."DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Government holds firm on not paying ransom to hackers
items.standfirst: The federal government is sticking to its position of not negotiating with cyber criminals, despite hackers releasing personal data from millions of Qantas customers onto the dark web and threatening to target Australia.
items.content: The federal government is sticking to its position of not negotiating with cyber criminals, despite hackers releasing personal data from millions of Qantas customers onto the dark web and threatening to target Australia.

ai_summary: Personal data of 5.7 million Qantas customers was released on the dark web.
Qantas was one of 40 companies affected by the hack.
The federal government will not pay a ransom to hackers.
Hackers threatened to target Australia.
Other companies affected included Toyota, Disney, and IKEA.

clusters.title: Community mourns as death toll from US munitions plant blast revised
clusters.neutral_headline: Death Toll Revised After US Munitions Plant Explosion
bullet_summary: A blast that levelled an explosives plant in rural Tennessee has left nineteen people missing and feared dead, authorities said

items.title: Community mourns as death toll from US munitions plant blast revised
items.standfirst: Authorities in the US say 16 people died in a massive explosion at a Tennessee munitions facility that has left a shocked community in mourning.
items.content: Authorities in the US say 16 people died in a massive explosion at a Tennessee munitions facility that has left a shocked community in mourning.

items.title: Nineteen feared dead in US explosives factory blast
items.standfirst: A blast that levelled an explosives plant in rural Tennessee has left nineteen people missing and feared dead, authorities said.
items.content: A blast that levelled an explosives plant in rural Tennessee has left nineteen people missing and feared dead, authorities said.Humphreys County Sheriff Chris Davis said the blast at Accurate Energetic Systems, which supplies the military, was one of the worst scenes he's ever seen. He said multiple people were killed but declined to say how many, referring to the nineteen missing as "souls" because officials were still speaking to family."There's nothing to describe. It's gone," Davis said of the plant.READ MORE: Putin praises Trump after failing to win the Nobel prize The blast occurred about 7:45am, Davis said, with aerial footage by WTVF-TV showing the smouldering hilltop facility and the burnt-out shells of vehicles.People reported hearing and feeling the explosion from kilometres away. The company's website says it makes and tests explosives at an eight-building facility that sprawls across wooded hills in the Bucksnort area, about ninety-seven kilometres southwest of Nashville.Davis said investigators are trying to determine what happened and couldn't say what caused the explosion.There's no further danger of explosions, and the scene was under control Friday afternoon, according to Grey Collier, a spokesperson for the Humphreys County Emergency Management Agency.Emergency crews were initially unable to enter the plant because of continuing detonations, Hickman County Advanced EMT David Stewart said by phone. He didn't have any details on casualties.Accurate Energetic Systems, based in nearby McEwen, did not immediately respond to a phone message seeking comment Friday morning."This is a tragedy for our community," McEwen Mayor Brad Rachford said in an email. He referred further comment to a county official.Residents in Lobelville, a twenty-minute drive from the scene, said they felt their homes shake and some people captured the loud boom of the explosion on their home cameras.The blast rattled Gentry Stover from his sleep."I thought the house had collapsed with me inside of it," he said by phone. "I live very close to Accurate and I realised about thirty seconds after I woke up that it had to have been that."State Rep. Jody Barrett, a Republican from the neighbouring town of Dickson, was worried about the possible economic impact because the plant is a key employer in the area."We live probably 15 miles (24km) as the crow flies and we absolutely heard it at the house," Barrett said. "It sounded like something going through the roof of our house."READ MORE: Palestinians return to what remains of their homes DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

The explosion occurred at a Tennessee explosives plant.
Authorities are mourning the loss of life.
Nineteen people are feared dead.
The blast leveled the explosives plant.

items.standfirst: British police have arrested two men on suspicion of murder after Ian Watkins, the disgraced former Welsh rock band Lostprophets singer who was serving a 35-year jail sentence for child sex offences, was killed in prison.
items.content: British police have arrested two men on suspicion of murder after Ian Watkins, the disgraced former Welsh rock band Lostprophets singer who was serving a 35-year jail sentence for child sex offences, was killed in prison.

ai_summary: Ian Watkins, former Lostprophets singer, was killed in prison.
He was serving a 35-year sentence for child sex offenses.
British police arrested two men on suspicion of murder.
The incident occurred while Watkins was incarcerated.
The investigation into the death is ongoing.

clusters.title: Benjamin Netanyahu booed as massive crowd gathers in Tel Aviv
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests in Tel Aviv as crowd gathers, Netanyahu booed

items.title: Benjamin Netanyahu booed as massive crowd gathers in Tel Aviv
items.standfirst: Thousands of Israelis have gathered in Hostages Square in Tel Aviv, where US envoy Steve Witkoff spoke to the crowd in anticipation of the release of the remaining hostages in Gaza.
items.content: Thousands of Israelis have gathered in Hostages Square in Tel Aviv, where US envoy Steve Witkoff spoke to the crowd in anticipation of the release of the remaining hostages in Gaza.

ai_summary: Thousands of Israelis gathered in Tel Aviv's Hostages Square.
US envoy Steve Witkoff spoke to the crowd at the event.
The crowd gathered in anticipation of hostage release.
Benjamin Netanyahu was booed by the assembled crowd.
The event focused on the ongoing hostage situation in Gaza.

items.title: Buyers priced out of market as developer finds sunset clause loophole
items.standfirst: Buyers who bought off-the-plan at a Gold Coast housing development years ago weren't just purchasing a home â€” they were purchasing a dream. Now, the developer is trying to cancel their contracts, but they don't want to accept that lying down.

The buyers are fighting to keep their purchased homes.

clusters.title: 'Why marry at all?' Woman upset at matchmaking service
clusters.neutral_headline: Matchmaking service draws criticism from Chinese Australian women

items.title: 'Why marry at all?' Woman upset at matchmaking service
items.standfirst: Chinese Australian women are paying thousands of dollars to find love on matchmaking platforms in Australia, but behind the glossy promotions lies a different reality.
items.content: Chinese Australian women are paying thousands of dollars to find love on matchmaking platforms in Australia, but behind the glossy promotions lies a different reality.

The services cost thousands of dollars to use.
The article highlights a different reality behind promotions.
